docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1948, when the State Legislature created the Board of Cooperative Educational Services, its goal was to allow local school districts to pool resources so they could save money and provide more services. The agency, known throughout the state as Boces, allowed districts to offer services like special education and vocational education that they could not afford individually. While Boces soon expanded to allow districts to share other special subject-teachers as well as business administrators, food-service managers and public-relations officials, the agency remained identified, in the public mind, with the disabled child boarding the special school van and the machine shop for students without the skills or inclination to go on to college.

headline.main: Boces Becomes a Technology Services Force

docs.abstract: Article describes role of New York State Board of Cooperative Educational Services in helping school districts on Long Island share costs of computer education; changes over past 50 years described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, officials from the National Football League Coaches Association, angry at what they thought was unfair treatment by the owners, met with Jeffrey Kessler, perhaps the most renowned sports antitrust lawyer in the country, in a hotel ballroom in Indianapolis. The topic of conversation? The N.F.L. assistant coaches were considering suing the league for antitrust violations. One of the assistant's biggest complaints has been that since the N.F.L. office keeps track of the salaries of almost every coach, and individual teams can find out approximately what those salaries are, there is almost a built-in salary ceiling. Some coaches wanted to sue to remove those restraints, members of the coaches association said last week. The N.F.L. says it in no way violates antitrust laws.

headline.main: Assistant Coaches Are Seeking Better Treatment From N.F.L. Owners

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was just after noon on Tuesday. Steve Bow had been zipped into his blue flight suit for hours, waiting calmly with the other crew members among the wafting medicinal vapors on the top floor of University Hospital, in Newark. He knew -- they all knew -- that it was only a matter of time. They were right.

docs.lead_paragraph: WOULDN'T you know it? Now that New York's reputation is all bright and shiny, everyone wants to drop by. Last year, a record 33 million visitors did just that. But not everyone has the welcome mat out. Tourism has been very, very good to New York. Visitors spent a whopping $13.7 billion last year, paid $710 million in taxes and generated thousands of jobs, as the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau is eager to point out. But many New Yorkers have grown weary of all the out-of-towners, who are showing up pretty much all year round. Some wonder if there are better ways to manage tourism that reap its benefits without sacrificing too much of the city's heart and soul.

headline.main: The Tourist Trap; With All Those Visitors Trampling the Welcome Mat, Can New York Be the Host With the Most for Everyone?

docs.abstract: Article on booming tourism in New York City now that city has cleaned up its image; record 33 million visitors flocked to city in 1997 but many people who work and live there say massive number of tourists is ruining their quality of life; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Bomb Suspect's Associate Sought Uranium, U.S. Says Federal authorities said a person they described as a senior deputy to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected in last month's bombings of American embassies in Africa, tried to obtain enriched uranium for a nuclear weapon in 1993. In court papers unsealed in Manhattan, the Government also asserted that Iran, Sudan and Mr. bin Laden had entered into a formal three-way agreement to work against the United States, Israel and the West. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the booming economy, the number of people without health insurance rose sharply last year, to 43.4 million, and the proportion of Americans lacking coverage reached the highest level in a decade, 16.1 percent, the Census Bureau reported today. After rising slightly more than 1 million a year, on the average, in the last decade, the number of uninsured people was up 1.7 million last year, the largest increase since 1992.

headline.main: AMERICANS LACKING HEALTH INSURANCE PUT AT 16 PERCENT

docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports that despite booming economy, number of people without health insurance rose sharply in 1997, to 43.4 million, and proportion of Americans lacking coverage reached highest level in decade, 16.1 percent; says number of uninsured people was up 1.7 million last year, largest increase since 1992; experts say there are several logical explanations for rising number of uninsured; Medicaid rolls are down as stringent new laws prod people to move from welfare to work and low-paying jobs they find often do not offer health benefits; some employers are cutting back health benefits because of rising medical costs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fallen Hedge Fund's Bets Are Put at $1.25 Trillion Long-Term Capital Management made complex bets on international financial markets with a total value drastically higher than previously estimated, financiers who studied its books said yesterday. They said the fund used its $2.2 billion in capital from investors as collateral to buy $125 billion in securities, and then used those securities as collateral to enter into exotic transactions worth $1.25 trillion. The portfolio had been previously estimated at $90 billion. The size of the fund's portfolio is extraordinary even in the world of hedge funds. How and why Long-Term Capital was able to make such astonishing bets remains unclear. [Page A1.] The 16 partners of Long-Term Capital still appear to be sitting on gains in their original investments in the hedge fund they managed despite the fund's near-collapse. [C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If health care costs grow substantially in the future (''Rising Costs in Health Care,'' editorial, Sept. 23), employers, who control almost all private health coverage, will push managed care companies even harder to cut back on care, and more employers will drop coverage for their employees.

headline.main: Replace H.M.O.'s With Universal Care; End the Link
